claim: People in England spend more time working now than in the past.

supporting.text: Technological advancements have increased remote work opportunities, allowing people in England to work longer hours outside traditional office settings.

attacks.text: Technological advancements have increased remote work opportunities, allowing people in England to work longer hours outside traditional office settings.
Remote work often leads to better work-life balance, reducing overall working hours as people prioritize personal time.
Studies show remote workers frequently work overtime due to blurred boundaries between work and home life.
Technological advancements have also increased automation, reducing the need for human labor in many sectors.
Automation primarily affects routine tasks, while knowledge workers face increased workloads due to higher expectations.

supporting.text: The gig economy has expanded in England, leading to more people taking on multiple jobs or side hustles, thereby increasing total working hours.

attacks.text: The gig economy has expanded in England, leading to more people taking on multiple jobs or side hustles, thereby increasing total working hours.
The gig economy often involves flexible or part-time work, which may not necessarily increase total working hours compared to traditional full-time employment.
Studies show that gig workers often work fewer hours than full-time employees due to the lack of guaranteed work.
The rise of automation and remote work has reduced the need for long working hours in many sectors.
Automation has primarily affected manufacturing, while the gig economy is more prevalent in service sectors, so the impact on working hours may vary by industry.

supporting.text: Labor laws in England, such as the Working Time Regulations 1998, cap weekly working hours at 48, which may limit increases in working time compared to the past.

attacks.text: Labor laws in England, such as the Working Time Regulations 1998, cap weekly working hours at 48, which may limit increases in working time compared to the past.
The cap on working hours does not account for unpaid overtime or informal work arrangements that may increase actual working time beyond the legal limit.
Studies show that enforcement of the Working Time Regulations is weak, and many employees are pressured to work beyond the cap without reporting it.
Historical data indicates that average working hours in England have decreased since the Industrial Revolution, contradicting the claim.
The decrease in average working hours is offset by the rise of multiple jobs or gig economy work, which may not be fully captured in historical comparisons.

supporting.text: Historical data shows that industrial revolution-era workers in England often worked 12-16 hour days, far exceeding modern average working hours.

attacks.text: Historical data shows that industrial revolution-era workers in England often worked 12-16 hour days, far exceeding modern average working hours.
Modern work includes unpaid overtime and digital connectivity, blurring traditional working hours.
Industrial revolution data primarily reflects manual laborers, while modern comparisons require service/knowledge economy adjustments.
Life expectancy during industrial revolution was significantly lower, making long hours unsustainable by modern standards.
Government data shows UK average weekly hours have remained stable (37-40 hours) since 1992 when proper recording began.
Victorian work patterns included frequent breaks and seasonal variations absent in modern continuous work cycles.

supporting.text: Increased economic pressures, such as rising living costs, have pushed many in England to work longer hours to maintain their standard of living.

attacks.text: Increased economic pressures, such as rising living costs, have pushed many in England to work longer hours to maintain their standard of living.
Official statistics show that average weekly working hours in England have remained stable or slightly decreased over the past two decades.
The stability in official statistics may not capture informal or undeclared overtime work, which has likely increased due to economic pressures.
Technological advancements have increased productivity, allowing people to maintain their standard of living without working longer hours.
Productivity gains have not been evenly distributed, and many workers face stagnant wages despite increased productivity.
Work-life balance initiatives and flexible working arrangements have become more common, potentially reducing average working hours.
Flexible working often leads to 'always-on' culture, where employees work longer but less measurable hours.

supporting.text: The adoption of flexible working arrangements and part-time work has grown, potentially reducing average working hours compared to past decades.

attacks.text: The adoption of flexible working arrangements and part-time work has grown, potentially reducing average working hours compared to past decades.
Despite flexible work arrangements, full-time employees in England often work unpaid overtime, increasing total working hours.
Studies show that unpaid overtime is declining due to stricter labor regulations and workplace monitoring.
The gig economy has increased the number of people working multiple jobs, leading to higher cumulative working hours.
Gig economy workers represent a small fraction of the workforce, and their impact on average working hours is marginal.
